issues.title: Proper documentation required ...
issues.body:
Spring petclinic previously had a really good [documentation](http://docs.spring.io/docs/petclinic.html) for beginners like me, but it`s outdated now. I have no idea on how it is working ... as it does not have proper documentation. Presentation attached is also very old one.

**_WITHOUT PROPER DOCUMENTATION(README) ITS NOT VERY DEVELOPER AND BEGINNER FRIENDLY._**
This documentation must have all howtos and how is it working in boot app...
Following can be some pointers....
1. Testing(Types of testing done)
2. Profiles
3. Internationalization
4. Validation
5. Explaining package structure.
6. SQL scripts
7. Caching
8. Templates
9. Application Configuration
10. JMX

 
I think documentation must also have a section of what is the difference between legacy spring app and this one: 

Following can be noted differences:

- Previously, app followed **3 layer architecture**, which is now outdated.(Why I don't know)
- Current package structure is also very VERY different, previously all entities were stored in `org.springframework.samples.petclinic.model`.
- Now, all settings are stored in application-* properties.
- Where did many things go.... it seems magic.... 
and so on....

Please make sure the documentation is very detailed like [this](http://docs.spring.io/docs/petclinic.html). but with much more details.

issues.title: Petclinic on Cloud Foundry
issues.body:
For demonstration purpose, we would like to host Spring Petclinic on Cloud Foundry.
It used to be hosted on Pivotal Web Services and it was kind of ok: http://spring-petclinic.cloudfoundry.com/ Only issue Michael noticed is that it used to have issues every 2 to 3 weeks. It would either restart or crash completely (so we had to redeploy it). It might be related to the application itself.
That was one year ago, so it might also be related to some issues with PWS that have been fixed in the meantime. 
See #126

I've got the same issue but on IntelliJ when I've clicked on the "Find Owner" button. Thus is not an Eclipse refresh problem.
Stacktrace:

```
org.apache.jasper.JasperException: javax.servlet.ServletException: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/json/simple/JSONValue
    org.apache.jasper.servlet.JspServletWrapper.handleJspException(JspServletWrapper.java:584)
    org.apache.jasper.servlet.JspServletWrapper.service(JspServletWrapper.java:454)

    org.springframework.web.servlet.view.AbstractView.render(AbstractView.java:303)
```

The json-simple-dependency comes transitively from the datatables-core dependency.
However, after a `mvn clean install`, the json-simple-1.1.1.jar is missing into the petclinic.war

I've got the same issue with Tomcat 8.0.18 when I edit the owner name with an empty value:

```
Etat HTTP 405 - JSPs only permit GET POST or HEAD
```

My question is why do we only have this error with invalid input?

A POST http://localhost:8080/owners/2/edit.html with `_method=put&firstName=Antoine&lastName=Davis&address=638+Cardinal+Ave.&city=Sun+Prairie&telephone=6085551749` is working but not with `_method=put&firstName=&lastName=Davis&address=638+Cardinal+Ave.&city=Sun+Prairie&telephone=6085551749`
In both cases, we go into the processUpdateOwnerForm method

Using both the `HiddenHttpMethodFilter`and the Spring tag `<form:form method="${method}"`, an hidden input field is generated: `<input type="hidden" name="_method" value="put">`. Thus the browser send a POST request wether the user edit or create a new pet owner.

The `HiddenHttpMethodFilter` wraps the original request into a `HttpMethodRequestWrapper`. Tomcat see a PUT method. 

This behavior changes in Tomcat 8 is described into this issue: https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=56568

Thaere is no workaround:
- Using  `%@page isErrorPage="true"%>`: no CSS / JS are loaded
- Using the PATCH verb: do not change anything
- Using the `AnyMethodHttpJspBase` class creates a link between the petclinic war and the application server

@michaelisvy what do you think about the #99 pull request?
@msuganthan the Spring `<form:form>`tag already add a "_method" hidden input field.
Thanks @mengelhardt for your help.
I think we may close this issue
Merge has been accepted. Thanks @trepel

Obviously it's a typo and the fix should be merged.

According to http://dandelion.github.io/components/datatables/1.1.0/docs/html/#4-2-feature-enablement, `dandelion-datatales` already supports pagination, and you'd turn on this feature by simply setting `pageable` attribute to true in related jsp files (e.g. `ownerList.jsp`), like this:

```
    <datatables:table id="owners" data="${selections}" row="owner" theme="bootstrap2" 
                      cssClass="table table-striped" pageable="true" info="false" export="pdf">
```

actually this issue comes from `dandelion-datatables`, which inserts another `bootstrap.css` after `petclinic.css` in html head section, and the style file specifies `.container` width as `1170px` (in line 5833).

to quick fix it, we'd just specify the width at the html element in related jsp file, e.g. `ownerList.jsp`:

```
<body>
<div class="container" style="width: 700px">
...
```
@lasiqueira your fix looks more reasonable, thanks!

I think it is a bug, it should (1) make the `setOwner` method in Pet.java to be `public`, and (2) replace `owner.addPet(pet);` with `pet.setOwner(owner);`

I guess, it is all because of "accomplishment", the Pet class has a variable called `owner`, if not set back `owner` object, it will return a `pet` with null owner (you'd debug it to see the value), obviously this kind of incomplete `pet` object is not acceptable for some use cases.

pull_requests.title: Create sample data programattically
pull_requests.body:
I find it much more maintainable to create sample data via code rather than in static SQL scripts.

The advantages in this case include:
* Removed duplication between `hsqldb/data.sql` and `mysql/data.sql`
* Don't need to synchronise database primary-foreign keys in the sample data
* Easy ability to reset data via a button on frontend
* I was able to extend this easily to create data in bulk (can create another PR for that if you want to see it)

<!-- --> corresponds to an html comment. It doesn't mean that the dynamic code shouldn't be processed. 
It just means the result won't be displayed in your page.

<%-- --%> means that Java code (and dynamic tags) shouldn't be processed.

http://spring-petclinic.cloudfoundry.com/
and click on "Error" on the menu bar. You'll just see an error message. Now have a look at the html source code. You'll see that an exception stacktrace has been added to html comment.

Just a quick update on that: this Eclipse bug has been resolved in Eclipse Kepler (4.3).

You can download STS 3.3 based on 2 Eclipse distribs: 3.8 (Juno) or 4.3 (Kepler). It has been done that way because Kepler used to be really slow (but it has improved a lot in the past 6 months).

So in order to have this bug fixed, you should download STS 3.3 based on Eclipse 4.3.

If you can't use that version of Eclipse, you still can disable the relevant validators. To do so:
1) Right click on the spring-petclinic project
2) Select "Properties"
3) Validation -> JSP Syntax -> Enable Project specific settings (and you should uncheck one of the options there, I don't remember which one as I'm using Kepler myself)
Should be all fixed now.

Sorry for not answering earlier. I missed your answer for some reason.

What you're trying to achieve is pretty well explained here:
http://www.mkyong.com/spring-security/spring-security-form-login-using-database/

In particular, you need to do something like that:

```
   <authentication-provider>
    <jdbc-user-service data-source-ref="dataSource"

       users-by-username-query="
          select username,password, enabled 
          from users where username=?" 

       authorities-by-username-query="
          select u.username, ur.authority from users u, user_roles ur 
          where u.user_id = ur.user_id and u.username =?  " 

    />
```

Hi,
sorry for being so late to answer. Are you still having that issue?

When you run "mvn package", JBoss is not used at all (because "package" only runs the Unit tests, it doesn't start up your server). So your issue could be that you're trying to connect to a datasource that won't be created until JBoss starts.
I did have the same issue as well. We've made some changes to the POM, I believe it shouldn't be an issue anymore.

Hi,
sorry for the late reply.
In Spring, the Hibernate.Dialect property that you refer to is called "Database". 

You can find this inside business-config.xml:

``` xml
            <property name="jpaVendorAdapter">
                <bean class="org.springframework.orm.jpa.vendor.HibernateJpaVendorAdapter"
                      p:database="${jpa.database}" p:showSql="${jpa.showSql}"/>
            </property>
```

And as you mentioned earlier:
jpa.database=HSQL

I'll add some comments inside business-config.xml to make it clearer.

Thanks for pointing this out. 
This is a common problem and you can find an elegant solution to it [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26757128/spring-mvc-sessionattributes-issue-in-multiple-browser-tabs).
Petclinic aims to propose a fairly simple architecture for people who are getting started with Spring so we will not implement that solution.

However, it reminds me that we should probably move our attributes to the request scope instead. This was highlighted by @jdubois a long time ago [here](http://blog.ippon.fr/2013/03/12/improving-the-performance-of-the-spring-petclinic-sample-application-part-2-of-5/). I'll create a separate issue for that.

Cheers,
Michael.

Because we are nice people :). We don't want to lock you in. 
Today Spring is popular so you can use it but it could be different 10 years later. So it's always better to use a Java framework that is not too intrusive in your code. In that way you can migrate to something else easily if one day you have to migrate.

Hi, I think I faced this problem one day because maven decided to not exclude spring 3.1 deps pulled by Spring Data.
I got tons of `ClassNotFoundException`, I fixed this purging my maven local repository.

nisuhw's fix would ensure that deps pulled by spring-data are upgraded to 3.2 version because they would be explicitly mentionned in the pom.xml.

I feel that the simplification will come the day when spring-data will upgrade to spring 3.2.

1. tomcat7 is a Maven plugin. Check the Maven docs or this online free book:

2. Just import as an existing Maven project and start Run as -> 'Run on Server' to start the the app on the Ecklipse's embeded Tomcat or VMware vFabric if you are using STS.

Hmm, that all seems very backwards (= too many LoC for little value) to me. With Java 8 (and e.g. jOOQ), I'm sure there's a more functional approach to generating nested collections in non-JPA environments...
You won't like my proposition :) (because I don't think a repository with multiple implementations is a good idea in the first place)

Sure.

In a JPA / Repository approach, you mostly operate on what a Java developer prefers to work on, i.e. domain objects written in Java. It is natural to navigate those objects in a rather imperative style, i.e. fetching the parent, and then iterating its children, possibly letting the ORM figure out what to fetch eager or lazy (hint: it's mostly wrong by default and needs tuning).

In a SQL approach (JDBC / SpringJDBC / jOOQ / etc.), you would do things very differently. You would think of your data as sets (or bags) of tuples (or rows), which you materialise all at once as required. You wouldn't fetch the pets and visits individually. You'd either:
- Join them.
- Fetch both sets in 2 queries and join them in memory.
- Nest sets via the `MULTISET` operator (unfortunately, not supported in many databases)

In fact, you probably wouldn't even make use of any extra DTOs which are just boilerplate in a SQL context. You'd pass the sets of tuples directly to the UI. If writing back to the database is required (it is here), then you'd probably use an active record pattern as implemented by jOOQ, to store the results that are modified by the UI directly, instead of expressing `INSERT` and / or `UPDATE` statements.

I'm aware that such a change would be a lot of work, but Spring has a lot of responsibility as well. You guys are an inspiration for a lot of programmers, many of which are not yet very experienced.

My take here is that if you're showing them the JDBC solution as it is now, they will get things wrong. They will think that JPA and JDBC are "similar", instead of learning to think in terms of sets and set theory, as they should when working with SQL...

> In case we would like to go that way, would you be interested to do it?

Only if I can contribute a jOOQ branch, too :) (disclaimer: I work for Data Geekery / jOOQ)

Note that jOOQ is commercial, but ASL 2.0 (dual-)licensed.

Here's some help for your argumentation showing how other commercial products can add value to Spring :)

Changing the `assertj.version` to 1.7.1 resolves this error.
No longer needed with the upgrade to Java 8.

Pinging @michaelisvy
I tried cloning the repo and running `mvn tomcat7:run` on Win 8.1 with Java 1.8_45
No dice.

Following [these instructions](http://graphwalker.org/docs/pet_clinic) I reset to cc4ae96, and manually changed plugin version to 2.2
Seems to work now but not the best user experience :wink:
So i have found out it was due to the changes to WLST and not tight to the packaging itself.
Has this been fixed in the code or why was this closed without reason?
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13629653/using-put-and-delete-methods-in-spring-mvc

review_comments.body: Any reason, why `@Override` annotation is remove

I have found a work around to deploy the application in tomcat as war file.

To deploy the petclinic application as war file in tomcat following changes needs to be done in pom.xml

Change spring-boot-starter scope to provided as below.

```
    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
        <artifactId>spring-boot-starter</artifactId>
        <scope>provided</scope>
    </dependency>
```

Comment all the jmx related entries in tools-config.xml as shown below

<!--     <aop:aspectj-autoproxy>
        <aop:include name="callMonitor"/>
    </aop:aspectj-autoproxy> -->

```
<!-- Call monitoring aspect that monitors call count and call invocation time -->
```

<!--     <bean id="callMonitor" class="org.springframework.samples.petclinic.util.CallMonitoringAspect"/> -->

```
<!--
    Exporter that exposes the CallMonitoringAspect via JMX,
    based on the @ManagedResource, @ManagedAttribute, and @ManagedOperation annotations.
-->
```

   <!--  <context:mbean-export/> -->

I will try to find out the actual fix for JMX related exception, but for now this will at least get your petclinic app up and running in external tomcat.
